title: 2009 Masters Tournament
text:
The 2009 Masters Tournament was the 73rd <a href="Masters%20Tournament">Masters Tournament</a>, held April 9–12 at <a href="Augusta%20National%20Golf%20Club">Augusta National Golf Club</a> in <a href="Augusta%2C%20Georgia">Augusta, Georgia</a>. <a href="%C3%81ngel%20Cabrera">Ángel Cabrera</a>, age 39, won his second <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major</a> title in playoff over <a href="Chad%20Campbell">Chad Campbell</a> and <a href="Kenny%20Perry">Kenny Perry</a>. Cabrera became the first (and only) Masters champion from <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>.
This was the final Masters appearance for three-time champion <a href="Gary%20Player">Gary Player</a>, and one-time champions <a href="Raymond%20Floyd">Raymond Floyd</a> and <a href="Fuzzy%20Zoeller">Fuzzy Zoeller</a>.
Field.
The Masters has the smallest field of the major championships, and officially remains an invitation event, but there is now a qualification process. In theory, the club could simply decline to invite a qualified player. This is the list of all 96 players who qualified to play in the 2009 Masters Tournament.

Par 3 contest.
The annual par 3 contest was held on Wednesday, April 8. <a href="Tim%20Clark%20%28golfer%29">Tim Clark</a> won with a score of -5 (22), two shots better than <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Mar%C3%ADa%20Olaz%C3%A1bal">José María Olazábal</a> and <a href="Jack%20Newman%20%28golfer%29">Jack Newman</a>. Three players shot a <a href="hole-in-one">hole-in-one</a>: <a href="John%20Merrick%20%28golfer%29">John Merrick</a> on the second hole, <a href="Greg%20Norman">Greg Norman</a> on the sixth, and Clark on the ninth.
Round summaries.
The Masters Tournament is played over four days with an 18-hole round being played each day, for a total of 72 holes plus practice rounds and a par-three contest on the neighboring par-three course. Everyone outside the top 44 and ties or outside ten strokes of the leader was "cut" after two rounds.
First round.
"Thursday, April 9, 2009"
The first round weather conditions were sunny and calm. <a href="Chad%20Campbell">Chad Campbell</a>, scored a 7 under par 65, which included five straight birdies in the first five holes. Campbell finished the day with a one stroke lead over <a href="Jim%20Furyk">Jim Furyk</a> and <a href="Hunter%20Mahan">Hunter Mahan</a>. <a href="Larry%20Mize">Larry Mize</a> shot a five under par 67 to be two strokes behind. Mahan led the field in total birdies with 9 in the first round.
Second round.
"Friday, April 10, 2009"
Campbell continued his strong play with a 2 under par 70 to remain in the lead at 135 (−9) with <a href="Kenny%20Perry">Kenny Perry</a>, who shot a bogey-free 67. <a href="Raymond%20Floyd">Raymond Floyd</a>, <a href="1976%20Masters%20Tournament">1976</a> champion, <a href="Fuzzy%20Zoeller">Fuzzy Zoeller</a>, <a href="1979%20Masters%20Tournament">1979</a> champion, and three-time winner <a href="Gary%20Player">Gary Player</a> completed their final rounds at Augusta. <a href="Anthony%20Kim">Anthony Kim</a> shot the day's low round with a 65, which included a new record for most birdies in a round with eleven.
The cut, the top 44 players and ties, was at 145 (+1), and fifty players advanced to the weekend. In all, 25 players shot sub-par rounds for the day and the scoring average was 73.74. For the tournament, 32 players were under par, and the scoring average was 72.99.
Amateurs: <a href="Reinier%20Saxton">Saxton</a> (+3), Newman (+4), <a href="Drew%20Kittleson">Kittleson</a> (+6), Wilson (+10), <a href="Danny%20Lee%20%28golfer%29">Lee</a> (+11).
Third round.
"Saturday, April 11, 2009"
Third round conditions were sunny, but with gusty winds that made scoring a bit tougher than the previous two days. Perry shot a two-under par 70 to remain in the lead at 205 (-11), with Ángel Cabrera who shot a 69. Campbell led for most of the day until a double bogey on the 16th hole and carded 72, two strokes back at 207. Jim Furyk finished another stroke back of Campbell. Five players shot the day's low round of 4 under par 68. Those players were: <a href="Jim%20Furyk">Jim Furyk</a> -8, <a href="Steve%20Stricker">Steve Stricker</a> -7, <a href="Sean%20O%27Hair">Sean O'Hair</a> -4, <a href="Ian%20Poulter">Ian Poulter</a> -4, and <a href="Steve%20Flesch">Steve Flesch</a> -3.
Final round.
"Sunday, April 12, 2009"
Summary.
<a href="Phil%20Mickelson">Phil Mickelson</a> birdied six holes on the front nine to score 30, tying the front-nine tournament record held by <a href="Johnny%20Miller">Johnny Miller</a>, <a href="Greg%20Norman">Greg Norman</a>, and <a href="K.%20J.%20Choi">K. J. Choi</a>. Third round co-leader Perry, age 48, led for most of the day; after birdies at 15 and 16, he disappointingly finished with bogeys at 17 and 18. He fell into a three-way tie at 276 (−12) with Cabrera and Campbell, leading to a sudden-death playoff.
Scorecard.
"Cumulative tournament scores, relative to par"
Playoff.
The playoff began on the 18th hole and Campbell was eliminated after failing to get up and down from the right greenside bunker. Perry was just off the green to the right, chipped close, and tapped in for par. Cabrera scrambled after an errant tee shot and a recovery shot that ricocheted off a tree, fortuitously into the fairway. His third shot from ended away and he holed the par putt to extend the playoff. The next hole was the 10th, and Perry failed to get up and down from left of the green; Cabrera two-putted from for par to become the first <a href="Argentinian">Argentinian</a> to win the Masters.
Controversies.
<a href="Rory%20McIlroy">Rory McIlroy</a> was involved in a controversial incident during the second round. In sixth place on the leaderboard with three holes left to play, McIlroy had double-bogeyed the 16th hole before hitting his approach shot into a bunker on the 18th hole. He failed with his first attempt to get the ball out of the bunker and kicked out at the sand, which could be an offense if it was deemed to be testing the condition of the hazard. He finished his round at 4:15 p.m. local time and at 8:40 p.m. was called to the clubhouse to view footage of the incident. He was later cleared of any wrongdoing, as a player is allowed to smooth over the sand provided that it does nothing to improve the position of the ball with regard to the next shot.
Also during the second round, while putting for birdie on the 15th green, <a href="P%C3%A1draig%20Harrington">Pádraig Harrington</a> had stepped up to his ball and addressed it, but a gust of wind caused him to step away. The ball then moved, but since he had grounded his club previously, he was deemed to have caused it to move and was penalized one stroke. He sunk the putt and, with the penalty stroke added, scored a par 5 on the hole.
